Award.AwardTitle: Runaway Slip: Understanding Nucleation of Subduction Megathrust Earthquakes and Slow Slip Precursors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zone earthquakes where 'runaway slip' allows faulting to rupture from depth all the way up to the seafloor can cause enormous tsunamis that devastate coastal population centers. Not all subduction zone earthquakes develop runaway slip- details of a particular fault's frictional behavior dictate what happens. This study will conduct laboratory experiments to determine how different types of fault rock respond to applied forces. Results could improve understanding of whether some subduction zones are more, or less, likely to generate megathrust earthquakes.

Current understanding of the mechanical response to shear stress of fault rock is limited by the lack of measurements on relevant natural samples at in-situ conditions. Laboratory shear measurements will document friction at in-situ pressures and temperatures using natural fault zone material. A transition in clay structure is thought to play an important role, along with mineral fabric and pore fluid pressure. A series of experiments on both crushed samples and intact wafers will be conducted. Start and end microstuctural and geochemical analyses will quantify the shearing impacts. Interpretation will focus on the nucleation phase of megathrust earthquakes. A female postdoctoral scientist will lead the study and the results will contribute to advancing knowledge within the GeoPRISMS program initiative 'Subduction Cycling and Deformation'.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subduction zones generate the Earth's largest earthquakes and tsunamis. In the past decade, focused research at several subduction zones has illuminated key aspects of earthquake behavior in these settings, most notably: (1) that seismicity generally initiates at depths greater than a few km, and rarely nucleates at very shallow levels; and (2) in the zones of transition from aseismic to seismic behavior, both above and below the region where large earthquakes nucleate, a host of slow earthquake phenomena occur. Despite these observations and a wide range of studies at particular plate margins, the mechanisms that control the transition from aseismic crepp to the nucleation of earthquakes, and more generally the roles of temperature, stress, and fault rock composition in controlling the style of slip on tectonic faults, remains elusive. 

This project aimed to elucidate these controlling factors through a comprehensive suite of carefully controlled experiments to define the frictional behavior for (a) synthetic fault gouges composed of clay components (smectite and illite) and quartz; and (b) a set of samples from scientific ocean drilling and field exposures that represent materials within the subduction plate boundary fault spanning from ~70 °C to >280 °C, and depths that cross the aseismic-seismic transition. The results show that with increasing temperature and increasing quartz (decreasing clay) content, both expected with increasing depth in subduction zones, there is a tendency to shift from stable sliding to unstable slip. This is consistent with earlier work on simple synthetic mixtures, and can be explained by a simple model of sliding of clay particles, combined with temperature-activated deformation of the quartz component. The results also show that with increasing stress or temperature gradient, the transition to unstable slip (i.e. where nucleation of earthwuakes is possible) shifts to shallower depths. Together, these observations advance our understanding of the underlying causes of the aseismic-seismic transition in subduction zones: i.e. why some portions of these plate interfaces (typically shallow depths) do not nucleate earthquakes, whereas deeper regions do host nucleation of events. The work will also help to guide the way forward for linking microphysical models with macroscopically - defined behaviors from experiments. Finally, the project provided lab training for a newly minted principal investigator, as well as opportunities for her to gain experience in mentorship of graduate students both within the geosciences discipline, and in an environmental and energy engineering program.
